Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 07:34AM Kimber wrote: orphan anne, When you see the genetic counselor, you will need all the ages of relatives at the time of diagnosis and/or death. (sorry to be blunt). I wasn't prepared for this and had to do all of my thinking right there. Then a simple blood test and just the wait for the results. My best to you and keep us posted! Kimber
Posts.Title: New to the Neighborhood orphan_anne Kimber

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 05:10AM Kimber wrote: Dense breasts make mammogram a little more difficult. You may want to see if you can get referred for an MRI. I have very dense breasts as well, and they grow two cup sizes before my period. I have had mammograms and a core needle biopsy 3 days pre-period. Anything "suspicious" stays the same as I had an MRI 7 days after period (they will only do it between days 7 and 14 of your cycle). I doubt you will want to or be able to "escape" a mammogram. Can you ask for some valium to calm your nerves? It works wonders! Good Luck!!!
Posts.Title: more questions before tomorrow tests paris9 iodine

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 05:17AM Kimber wrote: p.s. you are not compressed in the mammo machine very long. It's a matter of seconds. Try to be calm and it is helpful to try to take your mind somewhere else. I know it is hard, but it works. I have been through a lot, not only with cancer scares, but years of drugs and surgeries for infertility. Just remember you need to get through it to get the answers you need. The mammo techs are usually great at relieving your anxiety. Since you are not feeling well to begin with, I know it adds to your fears. You can do it, I know you can! IF they see something, then they will sonogram you. But again, I urge you to get an MRI if you can.
Posts.Title: more questions before tomorrow tests paris9 iodine

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2007 01:25PM Kimber wrote: Well, I'm home and the biopsy is over. They "drilled" into me 20 times (I have 2 spots that are suspicious). I think I saw another post on here where someone said it sounds like a back and decker drill. It sure does!! I bled a lot and am still bleeding. I was in the MRI machine for 1 hour and 45 min! With the holiday I have to wait until next wk before I know anything. Taking it easy now for the next couple days. My numbness is starting to wear off and I don't think I will be too happy in a little while.... Thank you for your thoughts and prayers everyone. I will let you know when I get my results. I am ready for whatever I am dealt. Hugs to all, Kimber

Posts.Title: Having a bad day..... Kimber Kimber

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 08:32PM Kimber wrote: My tissues are at the Mayo Clinic, so there is no calling them, and my doctor will call me as soon as he has them. My core needle biopsy showed PASH, which can also be mistaken for angiosarcoma, so that is why I am scared that they sent it to Mayo. That isn't a cancer you want to have. I would love to go drinking, but I have a 10 and 11 yr old to think about and I am not one to cry to my friends. I sort of do it alone. Sorry, I am not in a good mood today. But all of your suggestions were great. Maybe the vodka bath after the kids go to bed! Problem is, I can't stand to be bra-less right now.... Thanks for listening.
Posts.Title: Having a bad day..... Kimber Kimber

Posts.Content: Kimber wrote: Today is the first time I have let myself cry since my biopsy. For some reason I am most sore today and I just feel lousy. Could it be that I am just sitting here stewing??? :) I thought I would know by now, instead they sent it to Mayo and now I have to get through the wkd and maybe until my post-op appt next THURSDAY. What could it be? Why couldn't the pathologists here tell what it is - I am not in a remote area - I am in the Washington DC area! I go back and forth about the fact that they sent it to Mayo between good news and bad news, or something so ominous they are all up there in MN going "WOW this woman is a freak! We've never seen anything like THIS before!!!" I don't care what it is, I just want to KNOW. I can't get past the fact that they couldn't diagnose it yet. Sorry, just needed to vent..... Kimber Strong family history, Prophylactic Bilateral Mastectomies 1/19/2010, Under "reconstruction" for 6 months.... DONE! HAPPY! Dx 1/15/2008, LCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Having a bad day..... Kimber Kimber

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2008 04:44PM Kimber wrote: Thank you all! Thank you Tender for your great information! I have read all of that, but not the part about Mayo having the special stains. That makes sense. Don't get me wrong, I am glad they sent it to Mayo, I just wasn't prepared to wait longer. Shelle, I am healing OK, but I am very sore! I keep a sports bra on 24/7. One of my incisions is right around my nipple and is of course more sore than the other, which is straight out at 3 o'clock and about 2" long. That is the "suspicious" one. Did I tell you all that the original spot that started this whole mess was a STITCH from my breast lift in 2004??? It felt like a little bb, they thought it was scar tissue, but took it out to be sure, and it was a stitch! But if not for that little stitch, I would have never had an MRI that led me here. So whatever Mayo Clinic finds, I would have never been the wiser, and if it is bad news, I definitely caught it early because of that little bugger. I am better today, probably because I cried last night very hard and for a very long time. You all have been so great and so helpful. THANK YOU. I will keep you posted. BTW, Tender, where did you read that info on the stains, etc.? Love to all, Kimber
Posts.Title: Having a bad day..... Kimber Kimber

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 12:59PM Kimber wrote: Adrienne, I was not able to have biological children.  We adopted two beautiful children and they were absolutely meant to be ours.  If you could see the 4 of us together, you would see what I mean.  Things happen in mysterious ways - not always the conventional way..... My best to you for a quick recovery and on with your life! Kimber
Posts.Title: Here I Go Again? msvirgo828 redheadace1

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 06:11PM Kimber wrote: Leading up to finding the lump (which turned out to be nothing, but led to an MRI and then finding the bad stuff) I could not sleep, eat and I was in a constant state of "butterflies". I visited my family in another state, had a wonderful reunion, celebrated my 15th wedding anniversary....all the while knowing something was wrong with me. I kept telling my husband I couldn't figure it out. Then I did the self exam, found the lump, and all anxiety and butterflies went away. Although it was 4 months before I was fully diagnosed, I truly believed my body was tapping me on the shoulder. I say listen to your gut and get it further checked. Is it possible you have some sort of infection ?( you said you have a fever). My best to you, Kimber p.s. I agree with leaf - surgeons are not known for their personalities. They normally see us while we are asleep and draped up with only the spot they are cutting on exposed.....
Posts.Title: Results in, opinions/advice please. whatifitis leaf

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 08:43AM Kimber wrote: I think it is a good idea for you to take a happy pill if you have one! I am not claustrophobic, but the position you are in is very weird, and it is hard to stay still. I had to have my face in some sort of contraption that was supposed to be "memory foam", but all of the pressure on my cheekbones and forehead I found to be uncomfortable. They give you a button to push if you need anything, but for the most part I just tried to make my mind go somewhere else. I didn't have any happy pills, but I did when I had my MRI guided biopsy. You'll get through it - you will be surprised what you can get through when you need to! Good Luck!

Posts.Title: I have surgery on Monday Deidre flower123

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 07:24AM Kimber wrote: Deidre, It could be DCIS or LCIS - one is on the ducts, the other in the lobes. Call your doctor back and ask for a more clear diagnosis and maybe a referral to an oncologist. It may be a good idea for you to be on tamoxifen depending on your risk factors. In situ means it stayed "in it's place" and did not grow out. There is much controversy about whether it's pre-cancer or cancer. But try telling that to someone diagnosed with it! Once you have a more clear diagnosis or your path report, let us know. There are a lot of people here who can help you understand. You may also want to visit the DCIS or LCIS boards. Try and have a great Monday, Kimber

Posts.Title: WWWhhat! austin2k3 austin2k3

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2008 03:53PM Kimber wrote: oprygirl, Due to HIPAA, your insurance cannot cancel you. My genetics counselor had a special department that took care of finding out first how much they would cover and didn't run my bloodwork until I knew what I was responsible for financially. I was lucky, my insurance covered 100% and I didn't carry the gene. My genetics counselor also told me that insurance companies are actually preferring that you get tested because the alternative is more expensive to them Your genetics counselor will provide you with a lot of great information. Good luck! Kimber

Posts.Title: W A I T I N G. . . . Kimber awb

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 05:18PM Kimber wrote: The radiologist that did the biopsy told me that she would be the one calling me. My biopsy was the day before Thanksgiving, so she said it will be a little longer - probably the beginning of this week. I called yesterday and the nurse called back around 3 and said typically results take 2-3 business days, so figure on a call later today or early Wed. Well, no call today so I expect a call tomorrow or I am going to raise hell. It's the way things go with me. In 2006 I had a mole taken off my leg and it took 3 wks to get the results because they finally had to send it to a professor at the University of Miami, apparently a highly respected pathologist. No one could make a decision what it was because it had all of the characteristics of melanoma, BUT it was perfectly round. I still had to have a wide excision and now have a lovely scar on my leg, but no melanoma. So they are still probably looking at my whacky cells under the scope and wondering what the hell they are...... I hope to have news tomorrow. I appreciate your comments and I appreciate this board.
Posts.Title: W A I T I N G. . . . Kimber awb

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 08:02AM Kimber wrote: Thanks everybody, I am better today. Just hoping today is the day. I am going on with my schedule today and not sitting by the phone, although cell phone will be right with me! My gut says bad news anyway, so what time I hear it is irrelevant. I'm really not scared, I say BRING IT ON. I am healthy and stronger than my sister was when she was diagnosed and she is an 8 yr survivor. If not me, then it is going to be someone else today. I can handle it. Thanks for all your support. I'll let you know!
Posts.Title: W A I T I N G. . . . Kimber awb

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 12:52PM Kimber wrote: So sorry to hear about your results. Do you know what your plan is? I am waiting for my results too. It is agonizing! My treatment largely depends on the genetic results. I just found out my LCIS (if that is even what it is - the diagnosis has changed twice and gotten worse each time) is "multi-focal". So at the very least I need a re-excision or a possible mastectomy. Explaining this to people has been difficult. I guess when they hear you have breast cancer they expect you to have immediate removal of the monster and your hair to fall out right away. The staring at my chest has been laughable by people who know, but don't want me to know they know. Sorry, just venting......

Give us more info and maybe we can clarify for you further. Kimber
Posts.Title: excisional breast biopsy vs lumpectomy shells AlwaysHope

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 04:20AM Kimber wrote: shabby, I'm with ya sister.  My MRI is Nov 2nd -when is yours?  It's stressful....  I have never seen anything that has said mri can pick up malignancies that far in advance.  It only "lights up" things that don't seem to belong. A biopsy is the only thing that can confirm malignancy.   PM me and let's go thru the journey together.  Seems like we might be on the same schedule.  Are you on tamoxifen?  I have been for 20 months with no problems initially, but recently have been having such a rough time, I feel like quitting....  Any thoughts out there? xo Kimber

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 04:27PM Kimber wrote: I had a fine needle aspiration when I was 25 and I just had a core needle biopsy last wk at age 43. Neither one hurt. I was numbed for the core needle and didn't feel much but pressure. There are not a lot of nerve endings in breast tissue. I am bruised and sore but I have been more sore after a hard work out at the gym. Waiting for results is the hardest part. Just keep telling yourself this is something you HAVE to do, and take your mind to a happy place. It really does work.

Posts.Title: Anyone develop a seroma? Kimber 5yrsurvivor

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 08:45PM Kimber wrote: Hi everyone! Thank you so much for your comments and concern. In the last couple of days I have started to feel a little better. I posted on the hormone therapy board about body aches because I wasn't sure if I had an infection or it was an SE of the tamoxifen. The body aches have been better, although whenever I say that, they seem to come back. My surgeon seemed adamant about the fact that I could not get an infection "at this point" and said that he had let me know that I would feel this way and that I was to stay inactive. All I can say is that he must have another patient with my same name or that looks just like me, cuz I remember no such conversation about staying inactive "not even to gesture" for this amount of time. When I told him he hadn't had that conversation with me, he apologized and once again told me to not use my left arm for 2 wks. Ladies, I have gone from working out with a trainer 3 times a wk, bicycling 4 times a week and walking, running and weight lifting ( I can/could chest press on a balance ball 25 lb dumbbells, one in each hand) to DOING NOTHING. And he tells me the amount of fluid I have and the way I feel leads him to believe I have been "too active". Maybe I underestimated the lumpectomy and the amount of tissue removed, but I am also not a wimp and I feel like a big baby. I hate being so inactive. But like everyone says, for right now I guess this is my "new normal". Anyway, yes, I am feeling better, but I am sick of sports bras and dressing to conceal my gigantic boob. We are going on spring break and I have no idea what to pack, but in the big picture I feel really, really lucky. Thank you again to all of you wonderful ladies for your comments and concern. I always know where to come when I need to. Kim p.s. I have been using cabbage leaves on my breast for relief of the fluid and pressure and I think it has worked. Any questions I would be glad to fill you in.....
Posts.Title: Anyone develop a seroma? Kimber 5yrsurvivor

Posts.Content: Kimber wrote: If so, how long did it take to go away? Can I do anything to hurry it along? Any bra suggestions?? I am twice the size in my lumpectomy breast as my other breast. Surgeon doesn't really want to drain it as he is afraid I will become concave, and he is also afraid of introducing bacteria and me getting an infection. My surgery was 3 wks ago and I am still so sore and swollen. Sometimes I can feel the fluid pressing on my chest wall and between my shoulder blades. Can they drain SOME of it? I wonder if I wrapped myself it would help? I see the surgeon again on Thurs but I am just looking for any help or an ally in the meantime!! Thanks! Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 04:32PM Kimber wrote: Alicia, Given your family history, they want to watch you carefully and a baseline MRI is a good idea.  I would think that if the radiologist saw anything of concern, she certainly would have done a biopsy.  Are you dense??  Sometimes MRI is a better diagnostic tool that mammo for those of us with dense breasts.  My best to you, Kimber

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 02:23PM Kimber wrote: wishiwere, The 6 cm LCIS was removed by lumpectomy last Feb,  This is a new spot on the other side only located by MRI and is very near my chest wall - one person said in my ribs, another said in my muscle.  Yes, my surgeon was upset.  It's pretty bad when the technician at the hospital can't locate the clip, but techs at two other facilities were able to. They were amazed at how I handled it.  I think I am, too.  The surgeon told my husband that nobody can have their tissue pulled and compressed like I had and not feel like they have been hit by a truck.  A feel like that and then some.  leaf, I have a strong family history and have already had genetic testing.  I was just throwing that article in for anyone interested.  I have 2 sisters, one who is a 10 yr survivor and one who hasn't had cancer, and we thought the article was interesting for her (the non-cancer sister).   I don't bother with statistics myself, it is what it is.  Now I start the process of WAITING  for the results phone call.   YUK Kimber

Posts.Title: Unsubscribing HeatherBLocklear sueps

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 06:43PM Kimber wrote: Nicole, The MRI guided biopsy is done in the same way the MRI was done - you will be lying on your stomach with your breast in a coil, arms above your head and an IV inserted.  Yes, the test takes longer because they put you in the machine, take pictures, take you back out and then your breast is compressed slightly in a grid.  This allows the radiologist to then pinpoint the spot to be biopsied and biopsy it.  Now, this is the part that is a little unnerving.....it sounds like a Black and Decker drill.  If they have to place clips they will do that at this time as well.  Take the sedative and make sure you have a ride home - it really helps. No one can know until the specimen is under a microscope exactly what it is, so don't concern yourself with cancer or grades right now.  There is no way to know at this point.  It makes me mad when medical professionals speak before they should.  And REMEMBER - 80% of biopsies come back benign!!  If the only thing they saw on the MRI was this mass to be biopsied, then yes, it would appear that is the only "area of concern" right now.  My best to you - please let us know what happens.  PM me if you want to ask more questions about the biopsy. Kimber
Posts.Title: MRI Guided Biopsy anyone? nicky01 Nanorama

Posts.Content: Kimber wrote: OK ladies, I can tell you what hell is like because I was there on Monday.  I was scheduled for the wire localization at 11 and surgery at 1.  When I got to the wire localization and the tech looked at my films, she said "wow, this is REALLY deep!"  Ok first sign of things to come....  She took 12 views and could not locate the clip that was placed last Wed.  They called my surgeon who said to take me to another radiology dept outside of the hospital, and we went right away.  I spent the next THREE hours being smashed, grabbed, pulled, everything you can imagine to try to get my chest wall on film.  I finally ended up with 5 people in the room with me, all positioning me, one stayed with me pushing on my back and pulling on my breast inside the paddles!  Her hand is actually on my x-rays.  FINALLY they located the clip, the radiologist got the wire in and I went back to the hospital where they were waiting for me to operate. My surgeon did not seem to be to happy with the clip placement, he told my husband it was too much in my muscle.  I have never been so sore in my life.  I think all in all I had around 50 films taken.  I told them THEY were going to give me cancer!  Supposed to have results tomorrow.  Also, check out this article about the BRCA gene and women with a family history:  news.yahoo.com/s/hsn/20081117/...  I am not trying to scare anyone by sharing my experience!  The radiologist said she has been doing this 26 years and had never seen what happened to me.  Of Course!  Strong family history, Prophylactic Bilateral Mastectomies 1/19/2010, Under "reconstruction" for 6 months.... DONE! HAPPY! Dx 1/15/2008, LCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Kimber

Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 11:39AM Kimber wrote: I agree with Sam about the fact that you can feel your lump. But if you DO need a wire (I had 2) they usually tape them down, and they wheeled me through the back halls to surgery. I had a palpable lump (no wire) and 2 spots that showed up on MRI that were biopsied with a titanium marker. If you don't have any markers in your breast, there is no need for a wire. Best wishes with your surgery. Let us know! Kimber
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy scar/indentation clueless1 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: May 14, 2008 06:37AM Kimber wrote: SLH, I received the following on April 25, 2008: Dear Kimberly, Last week we told you about GINA – the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act – which if passed would make it illegal to discriminate based on genetic information. This protection is critical, since testing for a specific genetic mutation commonly associated with breast cancer can lead to early detection and treatment – saving countless lives. Now we have great news. More than 16,000 of you sent letters to your Senators in support of GINA, and it paid off! Thanks to your support, the Senate unanimously passed GINA last night (Thursday, April 25) and now the bill just needs approval from the House and the signature of the President – both of which are expected to happen quickly. GINA prohibits discrimination by health insurers and employers on the basis of genetic information. So now, thanks to GINA, women who would otherwise have avoided genetic testing because they feared discrimination – thus being denied information that could help them manage their health or their family's health – will have protections under federal law.  The passage of GINA is an important step that presents a great opportunity to promote personalized medicine and the use of genetic information in healthcare. This will lead to better research and development for new targeted drugs and treatments, which will save lives. GINA will become the law of the land.  And you helped make it possible. Thank you for your efforts, Diane Balma Susan G. Komen for the Cure Advocacy Alliance It sure looks to me like you have enough family history to be tested! Just my opinion.... Kimber

Posts.Title: MRI today Kimber Kimber

Posts.Content: Kimber wrote: Encouragement, discouragement...whatever.  After just having yet another surgical biopsy (that makes 6 + lumpectomy) all of a sudden I got a period, or vaginal bleeding whichever it may be.  Concerned about tamox, I called my oncologist and she told me to call my gyno and get an exam.  Then we talked about all I had been through and all the trauma to my breasts.  My lumpectomy scar is big - the chunk taken out was big, and before one of my surgical biopsies on my "good" side while trying to get the wire placed, I was mammogrammed 60 times because they could not get the clip on the film - it was close to my chest wall.  3 hours of constant compression!!!!   Anyway, her words to me were "peace of mind is worth a million bucks...every time you go through this it is a trauma to your breast, your body and your mind."  Soooo, I love my surgeon but am thinking about another opinion and talking to a plastic surgeon.  I have spoken to many of you about PBM, but want to know the deep down nitty gritty bad stuff.  What do I expect?    I mean, it's like an amputation! I'm not sure I can handle seeing myself that way... I have said all along I do not want cancer to make this decision for me.  With a mother, sister, and aunt all having bc, and my sister at 46, I just feel like it is only a matter of time.  Why not do it while I am young and healthy??  I feel like I am on a fence and just need a nudge to fall to the preventative side.  Sounds very silly when you put it in writing and think about it as strictly preventative.  SO many women here have done it and have been happy.  I am so sick of monitoring and the stress of biopsies before every holiday season..... Sorry once again to vent....this is a big decision for me.  How long will I be laid up?  How long will I need help with my kids?  I RUN my household - my husband can't even stand for me to have a cold.  How long does the process take??? Thanks sisters, I am in a weird place right now.... Kimber  Strong family history, Prophylactic Bilateral Mastectomies 1/19/2010, Under "reconstruction" for 6 months.... DONE! HAPPY! Dx 1/15/2008, LCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 02:01PM Kimber wrote: I had monitored for my wire guided biopsy and I don't remember a thing, other than being told it was over and me saying "already??" Having had MAC several times and also general, MAC is much easier to wake up from and you don't have that "medicine" taste in your mouth. I tend to get sick from general and had no probs with MAC. Do you have some valium or something to take for your wire localization? It really is not that bad, but you are left in the mammo machine for quite a while and I found that my chest hurt in the middle in the following days, I presume from being pulled away for so long. Good luck and let us know how it goes! Kimber
